    Invariant Kernels Basic Measure Theory Preliminaries

Invariant Kernels

Source: vignettes/Invariant_Kernels.Rmd
Invariant_Kernels.Rmd

General setting

Our general setting is a random vector \((X,Y)\) of interest with joint target measure \(\mu\). So, we have two marginal probability spaces \[(\Omega_X,\mathcal{F}_X,\mu_{\scriptsize{X}})\quad\text{and}\quad (\Omega_Y,\mathcal{G}_Y,\mu_{\scriptsize{Y}}),\] and a joint probability space \[(\Omega_X\times\Omega_Y,\;\mathcal{F}_X\otimes\mathcal{G}_Y,\;\mu).\]

We have corresponding conditional measures \(\mu_{X|Y}(\cdot | \cdot)\) and \(\mu_{Y|X}(\cdot | \cdot)\).

Let \(A\) be an joint event. We can define the following \(Y\)-slice event: \[A_Y := \left\lbrace \tilde{y} \;\in\; \Omega_Y \;:\; \exists\; \tilde{x} \;\in\; \Omega_X, \text{ such that } (\tilde{x},\tilde{y}) \;\in\; A\right\rbrace\] And a correspoding \(X\)-slice function \[A_X := \Omega_Y \mapsto \mathcal{F}_X \text{ such that } A_X(y) = \left\lbrace \tilde{x} \in \Omega_X \;:\; (\tilde{x}, y) \;\in\; A\right\rbrace\]

Basic identity

\[\mu(A) = \int\limits_{A_Y} \mu_{X|Y}(A_X(y)|Y=y) d\mu_Y\]

Invariance property

A Markov kernel \(P\) is \(\mu\)-invariant if and only if \(\mu(A) = \int P(A|z)d\mu\)

Single component invariance

Let \(P_{X|Y}[x,A_X(y)]\) be a Markov kernel and define the corresponding single component update kernel as \(P[(x,y),A] = \delta_y(A_Y) P_{X|Y}[x,A_X(y)]\). Then, \[P_{X|Y}[x,A_X(y)] \text{ is } \mu_{X|Y}\text{-invariant} \;\Longrightarrow\; P[(x,y),A] \text{ is } \mu_\text{-invariant}\]

Indeed, \[\begin{split} \int P[(x,y),A]d\mu &= \int\limits_{\Omega_Y}\int\limits_{\Omega_X}P[(x,y),A]d\mu_{\scriptsize{X|Y=y}}d\mu_{\scriptsize{Y}} \\ &= \int\limits_{\Omega_Y}\delta_y(A_Y)\int\limits_{\Omega_X} P_{X|Y}[x,A_X(y)]d\mu_{\scriptsize{X|Y=y}}\;d\mu_{\scriptsize{Y}}\\ &= \int\limits_{A_Y}\;\int\limits_{\Omega_X} P_{X|Y}[x,A_X(y)]d\mu_{\scriptsize{X|Y=y}}\; d\mu_{\scriptsize{Y}}\\ &=\int\limits_{A_Y}\mu_{\scriptsize{X|Y}}(A_X(y)|Y=y)d\mu_{\scriptsize{Y}} = \mu(A) \end{split}\]

Composition invariance

We can compose invariant kernels and mantain invariance. Let \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) be two \(\mu\)-invariant kernels and define: \[P_1P_2(z,A) = \int\limits_\Omega P_2(\tilde{z},A)P_1(z,d\tilde{z})\] To see that invariance is kept: \[\begin{split} \int\limits_\Omega P_1P_2(z,A)\mu(dz) &= \int\limits_\Omega\int\limits_\Omega P_2(\tilde{z},A)P_1(z,d\tilde{z})\mu(dz) \\ &= \int\limits_\Omega P_2(\tilde{z},A)\int\limits_\Omega P_1(z,d\tilde{z})\mu(dz)\\ &= \int\limits_\Omega P_2(\tilde{z},A)\mu(d\tilde{z}) = \mu(A) \end{split}\]

By induction we can extend this result to \(\lbrace P_k\rbrace_{k=1}^K\) \(\mu\)-invariant kernels, so that their compositions \[\overset{\circ}{P}_k(z,A) = \begin{cases} \int\limits_\Omega P_k(\tilde{z},A)\overset{\circ}{P}_{k-1}(z,d\tilde{z}) & k=K,\dots,2 \\[0.3em] P_1(z,A) & k=1 \end{cases}\] are also \(\mu\)-invariant.
